Lose yourself in the art of coding with the immersive work “Re:Coded” by the School for Poetic Computation, an artist run school and research group in New York that works closely to explore the dialogue between code, design, hardware and theory.

sessions.title: After Hours: Planetarium
sessions.description: Grab a drink, relax, and join us for a night under the stars featuring the psychedelic musical stylings of San Francisco's own “The Loyal Scam.” This instrumental trio of guitar, bass and drums performs classic tracks from the past, as well from the present. Visual accompaniments will be provided by the Chrome Music Lab team, showcasing their newest audio-reactive technology: Spectrogram. This space is sure to be experimental and weird in all the right ways.

sessions.title: After Hours: Tilt Brush Throwback
sessions.description: Tilt back and throw it back in this relaxing lounge featuring old school jams while experiencing live Tilt Brush art performances and Virtual Art Sessions.  Watch famed animators Chris Prynoski and Antonio Canobbio from the Titmouse Animation Studio create one of a kind Virtual Reality art in a 3D environment.

sessions.title: After Hours: Underwater Disco
sessions.description: Sway underwater while enjoying the indie dance tunes of Los Angeles-based DJ duo Poolside and Google's very own DJ Morale. Performing at high profile festivals like Coachella, Primavera Sound, and FYF, Poolside's music is best described as "Daytime Disco” and their sunny subaquatic tracks will get you moving. Opening and closing the disco, DJ Morale is known for his danceable downtempo grooves. Visuals for the space have been provided by the XL Catlin Seaview Survey in collaboration with Geo.

sessions.title: After Hours: Phantogeist with AR gameplay and Project Tango
sessions.description: Earth has been inhabited by aliens, and they are out to get you! Use your Project Tango device as a special scanner to defend yourself and Earth from the creatures by zapping them. Join forces with us to save the world!

sessions.title: After Hours: The I/O Arcade
sessions.description: Featuring interactive and retro gameplay, the I/O Arcade promises a plethora of options for gamers of all ages. Old school arcade games are paired with new school developer-centric games from Google Cast-enabled Games, Android TV Games, and Cloud Vision API. Test your skills in the Firebase Foosball Tournament or take on your friend in a one-of-kind virtual bike race. If gaming doesn’t suit your fancy, then preserve an I/O “moment in time” in one of our three unique photobooth experiences. Or heck...why not just do it all?

sessions.title: Android Layouts: a new world
sessions.description: Have you ever longed for an intuitive way to design your android layouts? This presentation will introduce a new layout engine and graphical design tools, and will cover everything you need to know to start using it in your own applications. The new system will help you quickly create layouts and iterate on the design, without sacrificing the powerful behavior expected of modern user interfaces.

sessions.title: Android NDK performance in an ART world
sessions.description: A look at how ART has altered the rules for NDK performance across several releases, along with a practical look at what developers need to do to maximize the potential of C/C++ code on Android.

sessions.title: Android application architecture: Get ready for the next billion!
sessions.description: Global smartphone usage is growing rapidly. However, network conditions around the globe vary. Plan ahead to make sure your users receive the best possible experience. We will talk about making your application "offline ready." This will include going through different use cases, and looking at how the user experiences in each can be improved dramatically by optimizing your app for bad or inconsistent network conditions.

sessions.title: Introducing Nearby: Physical proximity within and without apps
sessions.description: Nearby brings awareness of close-by smartphones, devices, and beacons to your app, using a combination of Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and ultrasound. Deep dive into Nearby's cross-platform, peer-to-peer API, as well as upcoming functionality for associating BLE beacons with on-device actions. We'll discuss Android and iOS features for relevant, proximity-powered triggers, sharing, group formation, and more.

sessions.title: Machine Learning: Google's Vision
sessions.description: Google has deployed practical A.I. throughout its products for the last decade -- from Translate, to the Google app, to Photos, to Inbox. The teams continue to make fundamental breakthroughs in machine learning, publishing promising new results at an accelerating pace. Now TensorFlow and Cloud Machine Learning make it even easier for researchers and developers around the world to collaborate. So as we work together to drive machine learning forward, what are the most exciting possibilities? What are the top challenges? And what's on the horizon? Join Google's machine learning leads in a discussion with veteran technology editor Tom Simonite as we explore the promise of machine learning.

sessions.title: Make money on Google Play
sessions.description: Google Play has built an incredible platform for mobile commerce. We're constantly investing in improvements to the platform. Developers interested in in-app transactions should attend this talk to learn about our platform, how it's improving, and how to make the most of it.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Firebase team
sessions.description: Have any questions about Firebase? Want to socialize with the team that built this product? Then be sure to come to our Office Hours. We will send our creme de la creme, all ready for those tricky technical questions you may have, or perhaps just a friendly chat. Be sure to join us!

sessions.title: Office hours with the Google Cloud Platform Team
sessions.description: Want to learn more about the many Google Cloud Platform products such as Cloud Machine Learning, Container Engine, App Engine, etc. or want to talk about building apps and services in the Cloud? Then Come talk to the PMs and DAs from the Google Cloud Platform Team. We're only too happy to help!

sessions.title: Practical lessons from a year of building web components
sessions.description: Web components are the new shiny thing on the web, but what makes a good web component? How do you design a useful API that works for all of your users and all of their browsers? How do you make it render quickly and how do you teach people how to use it? After a year of working on the Polymer Elements, I've made sure to make all the possible mistakes so that you don't have to. This talk is about the things I've learned from that.

sessions.title: Spatial Audio and Immersion - VR’s Second Sense
sessions.description: Human beings experience sound in all directions—like when a fire truck zooms by, or when an airplane is overhead. The Cardboard SDK enables mobile developers to create equally immersive spatial audio experiences in virtual reality (VR). Come join the Cardboard Audio team to learn how immersive audio works and why it is a powerful tool for guiding users through the  VR experiences you create by capturing their attention in a natural, intuitive way. In this talk, we will discuss the background and key aspects of spatial audio perception, virtual sound object rendering and acoustic room models in mobile VR.

sessions.title: Streamlining developer experiences with the Google Maps APIs
sessions.description:
The Google Maps APIs provide a seamless experience for developers of all levels. Some want to offer a map or navigation but don't want to build these things themselves; this can be achieved with just a few lines of code. Other developers prefer to integrate natively with off-the-shelf widgets. Finally, some developers want complete control over every aspect of the presentation.  

This session will highlight the Maps APIs representing the full gamut of the developer experiences, enabling you to get going immediately and scale as necessary. You'll see how widgets and services can be added over time with a suite of Maps APIs, services and libraries.

sessions.title: The new Cast SDK
sessions.description: Enabling your apps with Google Cast is getting easier and easier. Millions of users press the Cast button every day to connect their mobile device with the best display in their homes. If you’ve wondered how this is done or are an experienced Cast developper, this session will take you through all the details. We’ll go through recent updates on Android and iOS - including how we’ve made it easier to discover devices, handle reconnection, and manage the entire user experience in a Cast session. Come listen to Adam Champy, Product Manager for Google Cast, share these updates.

sessions.title: 3rd Annual Google Security Update
sessions.description: Join Google's Security Engineering team for the third annual security update, full of interesting things we've worked on over the past year or so to protect our users all over the world. Beyond things we've done, we'll also talk about some forthcoming APIs as well as security best practices that we'd like to encourage you to adopt, as developers, as companies, and as individuals.

sessions.title: 6 Degrees of Freedom Gaming in Android with Project Tango
sessions.description: Project Tango transforms the way we play games by understanding your phone's precise 3D motion. Chase a virtual pet around your home, tag ghosts with your phone and fling rocks at castles in 3D. Gaming is the most popular app category for Project Tango - over 2/3 of all the Project Tango apps on Google Play are games. Learn how to build a simple Project Tango game along with some tips and tricks for development.

sessions.title: Bridging the physical and digital. Imagine the possibilities. ATAP.
sessions.description:
Optimized for speed and agility. Diversity and scale. Ambitious blue sky research coupled with a driving application. Because we don’t believe in false choices.

Projects that integrate our physical world with our digital lives… that connect us with our humanity and leave us with a sense of wonder. Fabrics that interact. Radars that sense. Platforms that are modular. Computers with a new vision. A feast for your eyes and ears in 2D, 360 and VR.

ATAP + developers + commercial partners… showing the world that the seemingly impossible is possible.

sessions.title: Bringing seamless checkouts to the mobile web
sessions.description: In recent years we've seen incredible growth in the number of users shopping on the mobile web. Checkout flows, however, haven't changed and remain stuck in the past. This session will encourage you to "think outside the app" to explore how you can bring a seamless, one-tap checkout experience to your mobile website.

sessions.title: Designing for Daydream
sessions.description: Daydream is an entirely new platform with an entirely new set of design considerations. In a series of lightning talks about VR design, the team will cover: knowing your users, ergonomics, environmental design, and the new Daydream controller.

sessions.title: Developing successful games with Google Play
sessions.description: Google Play Games have been providing tools to engage, retain and monetize players for developers. In this session Ben Frenkel, TI Chang and Duke Kim will (1) present how Google Play game services can help game developers, (2) share implementation best practices, and (3) provide insights from integrating Google Play game services into AAA-quality mobile games respectively.

sessions.title: High Performance Games and VR with FPL Technologies
sessions.description: Games dominate the Play Store, and soon, VR may too. What does it take to produce quality 3D and VR content to create smooth user experiences without overheating the battery? Come hear how the cross-platform C++ technologies from Fun Propulsion Labs at Google can help you build more efficient experiences on Android and beyond.

sessions.title: Machine learning is not the future
sessions.description: AI and machine learning have been a topic of science fiction for years, and they'll continue to be. But this talk isn't about science fiction—it's about all the amazing new things that machine learning is already doing for us today. It is already around us, in many many products. See where machine learning is used today and how you can use TensorFlow to make it a part of everything you do.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Android Location & Context team
sessions.description: Have questions about location, proximity or sensors on Android? Have a chat with the leads for the Location, Geofencing, Places, Sensor, Activity Recognition and Nearby APIs.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Android Runtime & Tools team
sessions.description: Come with your questions for the Android Runtime & Tools team, which includes the Android Runtime (ART), the Java Core Libraries, the Jack compiler, the Bionic C library, the Native Development Kit (NDK), and Renderscript.

sessions.title: Recipes for App Development with Firebase
sessions.description: Calling all mobile developers! The Firebase platform provides so many great tools for building your app. In this session, learn about how to all of these components together to bring a mobile app from idea to market to profit.  We'll take a look at some potential app concepts and see how Firebase can provide the infrastructure to make them successful.  We can't wait to see what you build!

sessions.title: Zero to App: Develop with Firebase
sessions.description: Firebase helps mobile and web developers create extraordinary apps. It abstracts complex infrastructure and simplifies the development process. By using Firebase, developers can build the best user experience in the shortest amount of time, all without having to spin up servers or manage infrastructure. We'll explore how Firebase authenticates users and synchronizes data by creating an app on stage. You'll experience first hand how easy it is to build with Firebase!

sessions.title: Bringing live content to Android TV
sessions.description: Channel surfing is a popular way of watching TV. You pick up the remote, lean back, and flip through channels to see what’s on. On Android TV, app developers can create their own channel-like experiences using the TV Input Framework. To the user, the channels you create look and feel just like regular TV channel. If you already have an app that streams video, consider also making your content available as a channel. Come listen to our talk to learn more about the benefits of using the TV Input Framework and how you can start building your channel.

sessions.title: Configuring the world: Rapid actioning based on analytic insights
sessions.description:
You built your app and you launched!  Congratulations!

And now you're gaining fascinating insights on user behavior thanks to Analytics and you're itching to take action based on these insights. You can always go back to changing your app and pushing a new version, hoping your users will update your app. But there is a faster way to make changes: Firebase Remote Config.

Firebase Remote Config is built for just this kind of rapid reaction to user insights. In this talk we will show you how a deceptively simple system for targeting and distributing key-value pairs can be leveraged to easily modify your app look and feel without having to constantly update your app itself. We will show you example with code and also discuss a few real world examples from early adopters of Firebase Remote Config.

sessions.title: Dan Lyons (Disrupted: My Misadventure in the Start-up Bubble) in conversation with Chris DiBona
sessions.description: Dan Lyons is a veteran technology journalist who worked at Forbes and Newsweek. He was the voice behind Fake Steve Jobs, and The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, and later worked on two seasons of Silicon Valley, the HBO comedy. His new book, Disrupted: My Misadventure in the Start-Up Bubble, is a New York Times Best Seller and a hilarious chronicle of his mishaps trying to fit in as the "old guy" at a software startup where he was twice the age of everyone else. It's a funny book but Dan also takes a serious look at the dysfunctional culture of startups and in Silicon Valley in general. In a conversation with Chris DiBona, Dan will talk about the ideas he explores in "Disrupted." He'll also talk about how he ended up working on "Silicon Valley," and what it was like working in the room with a team that included former Twitter CEO Dick Costolo.

sessions.title: Deep user engagement with web push notifications
sessions.description: Push notifications are an incredibly effective way to build deeper user engagement with your application, and are now available on the web. In this session, we'll take a look at how they work and deep-dive into how to implement push notifications in web applications, from beginning to end.

sessions.title: DevTools on RAILs
sessions.description: Let Paul Irish show you new tips, tricks and features in DevTools (and beyond!) that help you debug the performance of your site. Measuring your key user interactions and diagnosing your bottlenecks is key, and Paul will illuminate the best practices by showing performance opportunities in real world sites.

sessions.title: Election 2016: The big data showdown
sessions.description:
The US election is still months away, but a massive amount of data has already been generated on the topic. From social media to campaign finance disclosures to newspaper articles to poll results, we are awash in data about the candidates. How can we separate the signal from the noise, and figure out what it all means?

This talk takes a number of disparate sources of data; reddit comments, federal election disclosures, and a global event database as the raw materials to use Dataflow, Datalab, Cloud ML, and BigQuery, to extract meaning from it all. We'll find out what people are saying, in real-time, about the candidates. We'll show how to build a dashboard that can display front-runners in the campaign donation race, the reddit popularity contest, and more. 

You'll see how you, too, can gain insight from disparate data sources by harnessing the suite of tools in Google's cloud.

sessions.title: Find 'Em, Keep 'Em: How Ads Get You the Best App Users
sessions.description: Attracting valuable users is crucial for long-term app success. You want users who will stick around for longer than one session, earn you revenue and spread the word to their friends. Google's machine learning is helping the most successful apps find the right users with ads, and retain them. Getting started with Google ads is simple, yet unlocks a huge range of ad formats that promote your app to billions of users. In this session, master when and how to run ad campaigns, while minimizing costs.

sessions.title: Inclusive design and testing: Making your app accessible
sessions.description: Nearly 20% of the U.S. population will have a disability during their lifetime. Developers can increase their user base and create a better experience for everyone by making their app accessible. APPlicable, a Campus Tel Aviv program, helps startups make their app accessible to people with disabilities by inviting startups to witness how blind and motor impaired users use their apps. In this session, we will present lessons learned and provide guidelines for creating an inclusive design. We will also present automated testing tools that provide suggestions to enhance accessibility.

sessions.title: Live coding: Make a virtual reality game
sessions.description: Let's make a virtual reality game! Join Shanee Nishry for a live coding session using the Unity Cardboard SDK to create a virtual reality game. By the end of the session we will have a small yet fun "defend the castle" game with a terrifyingly cute enemy army and a player controlled cannon to fend off the attack. We'll explore stereoscopic rendering, user controls using input and the Cardboard Reticle and even add 3D real-time binaural audio!

sessions.title: Office hours with Android app performance teams
sessions.description: Android app performance matters! We work on making Google's apps faster. Ask us about code performance, memory, threading and priorities, Proguard, and keeping your APK size small.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Android Multi-Window team
sessions.description: Come chat with members of the Android Multi-Window team to get your questions answered on the new multi-window functionality and APIs in N.

sessions.title: RecyclerView ins and outs
sessions.description: Since its debut at IO'14, RecyclerView has come a long way and has become the de-facto list component on Android. Come and learn about the history of ListView, what we've learned from it and how we've designed RecyclerView based on these learnings. We will discuss the internal architecture of the RecyclerView, how it handles different layouts, animations and UX flows. We will also go through some of the best practices so that you make the best of RecyclerView in your applications.

sessions.title: The Physical Web: Make It So
sessions.description: You've heard about the Physical Web, now find out how to make it work for you. We will cover: best practices for configuring and deploying beacons, how to provide metadata for notifications to users, how to use Progressive Web apps to create native experiences, and how to use the Web Bluetooth API to control physical devices.

sessions.title: Best practices for a great sign-in experience
sessions.description:
Are you losing users at sign-up or sign-in for your app? Google research has found that half of people get stuck on the sign-in screen. Building a secure and usable auth experience is difficult and time-consuming.

Google’s Identity Platform provides solutions to these problems drawing on principles derived from years of experience with one of the world’s largest account systems. Whether you are a new developer or already have an existing sign-in system, we can help you maximize conversion. We’ve revamped Google Sign-In, expanded Smart Lock functionality, and overhauled our identity-as-a-service solution.

Make use of these products today to keep your most engaged and valuable users signed-in across web, iOS, and Android.

sessions.title: Breakthroughs in machine learning
sessions.description: Advances in machine learning are powering new products from speech recognition to Smart Reply. But how does the "intelligence" in these systems actually work—what's going on inside a finished product, and what major challenges remain? In this session, we share a behind-the-scenes look at three machine learning technologies we're working on at Google.

sessions.title: Design Fireside Chat
sessions.description: If you're a developer working with a designer, this conversation with design leaders from Google will address some of the issues you may face in the workplace. If you’re a designer or product person, you’ll come away with an insider’s view of how teams collaborate at Google. We’ll cover a broad range of topics including the challenges of creating for multiple platforms and form factors, how to establish brand guidelines that work for your team, design sprints, prototyping, research, accessibility, and streamlining workflows between product, design, and engineering.

sessions.title: Enhancing Applications and Websites with Embeddable VR Views
sessions.description: Travel apps may include turtle photos, but they're nothing like diving into the open ocean. Real estate websites may include descriptions of the dining room, but it's nothing like actually touring the home. For developers, having immersive elements in their apps and websites can be the difference between meh and magical. This talk explains how to use VR Views to quickly and easily enhance your website or native app with immersive, 360 media elements.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Android Battery & Framework teams
sessions.description: Have questions about changes to background activity in Android? Want to understand how to efficiently perform background activity? Want to understand the battery impact of your app, or how Doze and App Standby work? Come have a chat with members of the Android team responsible for battery and memory management as well as JobScheduler APIs.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Search & AMP team
sessions.description: Come get your questions answered on how to grow your business with Search. This includes AMP, App Indexing, Rich Cards, and Search Console.

sessions.title: Printing from your app: From pixels to paper
sessions.description: Come and learn why printing is important for both you and your users in the mobile first world. We'll show you how to add print capabilities to your app and cover best practices, common pitfalls, and how the Android print framework puts pixels on paper.

sessions.title: Progressive Web Apps across all frameworks
sessions.description: Progressive Web Apps can be built using any JavaScript library or framework, whether it's React, Angular 2.0, Ember or Polymer. In this talk, we'll dive into how to craft offline, lightning fast web apps using each of these solutions. Learn how to take advantage of Service Workers, Server-side Rendering and an application "shell" architecture to optimise for first meaningful paint, fast-first load and repeat visits. We'll also cover techniques for progressive-enhancement using these libraries so your users still get the best user experience supported by their browser.

sessions.title: The 2016 Web Development Workflow
sessions.description: In this session, we will take a retrospective look at old workflow tools, future web tooling paths, the web's unifications efforts, and arguments for why tools are dead, and why the only hope we have is to embrace the platform.

sessions.title: The Evolution of ART
sessions.description: ART is the runtime which powers the entire Android platform. Come discover how we've improved the Android runtime to better serve a rapidly evolving ecosystem. From monthly system updates to incredibly rich and powerful apps, mobile development is growing more and more complex. In this session we will present the strategies we adopted to improve Android performance and minimize update times and disk usage. We will be talking about the new exciting Hybrid JIT-AOT approach, profile guided compilation, the new compiler and application images.

sessions.title: Turbocharge app conversions with Android Pay
sessions.description: Learn how you can implement the new Android Pay API to power fast, secure checkouts in your apps, and drive more sales for your business.

sessions.title: VR in the Classroom: Early lessons learned from Google Expeditions
sessions.description: Virtual reality has the potential to change how we teach and how we learn. But how do we leverage VR's potential to actually transform learning? The Google Expeditions team will share what they've learned about making compelling VR apps for the classroom.

sessions.title: Best practices for orchestrating the Cloud with Kubernetes
sessions.description: In the last decade, user demand for always-on applications have grown exponentially. Many developers choose application patterns to meet this need, but what about the infrastructure needed to support these ever growing demands? In this talk, we will introduce you to the next level of automation using hands-on examples of industry standard tooling like Docker, a container format, and Kubernetes, a distributed automation platform. We'll cover the basics of modern day applications and how design patterns like microservices drive the need for more robust infrastructure. Then we'll cover packaging and distributing apps using Docker. Finally, we'll up our game to running applications on Kubernetes. By the end of this talk you'll have the knowledge needed to excel at scale.

sessions.title: Bring your Android app to Android TV in minutes
sessions.description: Bringing your app to the living room can be done in less time than you may think. Join us in this talk, where we'll show you how to port your existing Android app over to millions of Android TV devices in minutes. We've also got some great tips on how to make your app shine on the big screen. Lean back and watch how easy Android TV development can really be, using Android Studio, libraries such as Leanback, and the provided Android TV emulator.

sessions.title: High performance web user interfaces
sessions.description: Users expect Progressive Web Apps interfaces to be responsive and intuitive. In this session we’ll dissect some UI components, and see how we can build them in a performant way that delights our users.

sessions.title: Houdini: Demystifying the Future of CSS
sessions.description: The engine that drives CSS is mostly working in the background, consuming the stylesheets we write. Houdini is a collaboration between browser vendors to specify and implement new JavaScript APIs that expose these internals of the engine to developers.

sessions.title: How AMP achieves its speed
sessions.description: The Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) project’s primary goal is to make mobile web pages ridiculously fast, to the point where they appear to load instantly. Watch AMP engineering lead Malte Ubl dissect the anatomy of AMP and all of its performance insights and optimizations, to ultimately give you the power to control your own performance destiny.

sessions.title: Improve User Acquisition Campaigns with Firebase Analytics
sessions.description: Got a great app and want more users? Having a user acquisition strategy is crucial to global app domination, but it doesn't have to be a leap in the dark! This talk shines a light on how you can run both organic and paid app install campaigns to deliver real results in a cost-effective way -- and how Firebase Analytics ties it all together. You’ll learn how to track user acquisition performance, understand the right metrics to compare ad networks and see why lifetime value really matters.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Android Pay Team
sessions.description: Interested in delivering a quick and seamless payments experience to your customers? Want to know how to implement the new "Save to Android Pay" API? Want to experience our tap and pay feature and claim a give away? Stop by the Android Pay Office Hours to meet with our senior Engineer and Product Manager -- the brains behind our new API offering.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Nest team
sessions.description: For years, we’ve been talking about home automation. There are universal remotes, wall panels and apps to control devices in your home. But Works with Nest is more than just an on/off switch. It’s about making your house a more thoughtful home, working securely behind the scenes to interact with things you already use every day. And, as a result, making your home safer, more energy efficient, and more aware. Learn more about the Works with Nest developer program and join us in making this vision become reality.

sessions.title: Progressive Web Apps on Firebase
sessions.description: Progressive Web Apps offer a first-class mobile experience for users, but can be daunting to approach the first time you build them. Luckily, Firebase offers a first-class development experience for building Progressive Web Apps! In this session, we'll take a Firebase-powered web application and turn it into an offline-ready, service-working, app-manifesting, production-ready Progressive Web App using Firebase Hosting, Auth, and Database. We'll walk through how to add Progressive Web App capabilities to an existing app, how to cache app shell and Firebase Database data offline, and how to deploy your PWA to Firebase Hosting.

sessions.title: Service workers at scale with Facebook and Flipkart
sessions.description: Service workers provide the technical foundation for Progressive Web Apps and unlock the ability to build rich app-like experiences on the web. Come and listen to Facebook and Flipkart talk about how they are taking advantage of this new primitive and seeing real business impact by implementing offline features, lightning performance and push notifications on their web properties. This talk will cover architectural overviews of what they built, the impact the saw, and real world advice about using service workers in production at web scale.

sessions.title: VR & Cinema
sessions.description: Filmmakers breaking into virtual reality face an entirely new set of challenges; creating for a new medium requires a new perspective. Join Google's Principal Filmmaker for VR, Jessica Brillhart, as she explores the emerging landscape and language of cinematic VR – providing some of her own insights from being a creator in this field while highlighting experiences produced by the world's most prolific VR content creators.

sessions.title: Building High Performance Daydream Apps
sessions.description: Creating great smartphone VR experiences is fundamentally hard. VR applications must render stereoscopic 3D scenes at high frame rates for long periods of time, all without overheating the phone or regularly dropping frames. This talk will cover a range of techniques - from the new Daydream APIs to high level best practices - that allow developers to deliver incredible, low latency, high quality experiences on Daydream.

sessions.title: 5 Neat Tricks You Can Do With The Firebase Platform
sessions.description: So there's a lot of fun things you can already do with the new Firebase platform if you look at any individual feature. But let's take a look at some of the amazing tricks you can pull off when you combine some of these features together! Can you use the new Firebase platform to find your big spenders and send them a notification telling them about a hidden sale before the rest of your customer base? Well, I guess this presentation would be pretty boring if the answer was "no", but drop by and find out, anyway!

sessions.title: A window into transitions
sessions.description: Motion helps guide your users through your app by providing hierarchy and spacial relationships. Transitions are the best way to implement this kind of scene change and to choreograph the journey through your app. This session provides a deep dive on Android’s transition APIs focusing on content and shared element transitions. Learn how to use transitions provided by the framework and to write your own.

sessions.title: AMP + Progressive Web Apps: Start fast, stay engaged
sessions.description:
AMP delivers outstanding page-load performance for users browsing content on the mobile web, which is hugely important on limited or flaky networks. AMP gets content in front of users fast.

Progressive Web Apps deliver reliable performance for re-visits to sites thanks to Service Workers and the App Shell architecture. This technique allows sites to deliver rich experiences without worrying about networks.

Until now, however, these approaches for accelerating the mobile web have appeared to be in conflict. What if it were possible to use them in conjunction to deliver fast initial loading and reliable second-visit performance, as well as advanced features like offline reading and richer UI treatment?

Come learn about how to make AMP-based PWAs and hear about how this architecture is working for real-world publishers today.

sessions.title: Android N Office Hours
sessions.description: Come ask any questions you have on Android N, or on the Android platform in general; engineers from the Android platform team will be on hand to help you out.

sessions.title: Designer & developer communication
sessions.description: Let's be honest – communication between designers and developers isn't always perfect. The knowledge that comes with each discipline stems from entirely different skill sets. Designers and developers often have different priorities, even though everyone is working toward one common goal: a fantastic, delightful, functional product. At Google, we're always working on ways to bridge this gap through unified spec formats and tools, so that intricate details are never lost in translation and things get done the way they're intended the first time. Join a conversation with Google designers and engineers as they share tricks they've discovered over the years to successfully communicate and implement visual and motion design for dozens of Google products.

sessions.title: Fireside Chat: Firebase in the Real World
sessions.description: Developers face many challenges to establish a successful business. Firebase is Google's solution to help developers succeed! Join us for a discussion with developers across different sectors and regions to hear how they are using Firebase to develop, grow, and monetize their business.

sessions.title: Mobile Web Office Hours
sessions.description: Have questions about mobile web development? Stop by for a chat with our engineers and developer advocates to discuss your questions on Progressive Web Apps and more!

sessions.title: Office hours with the AdWords, AdMob & Analytics team
sessions.description: Meet our AdWords, AdMob and Analytics experts. Our product managers and developer relations teams will answer your questions about mobile app user acquisition with AdWords Universal App Campaigns, technical API and SDK questions for AdMob, and how to leverage Analytics for installs and monetization.

sessions.title: Office hours with the Firebase team
sessions.description: Have any questions about Firebase? Want to socialize with our team? Then be sure to come to our Office Hours. The engineering team will be ready for those tricky technical questions you may have, or perhaps just a friendly chat. Be sure to join us!

sessions.title: Office hours with the YouTube team
sessions.description: Have questions about using video in your app? Want to know how to build an awesome app on top of YouTube? Want to understand how to build a service YouTube creators will love and how to get insights from your YouTube data? Come chat with the YouTube developer relations team, the people behind YouTube's APIs.

sessions.title: One lap around the Google Cloud Platform
sessions.description: Come find out what is NEXT with the Google Cloud Platform. In this session you will learn how the latest advances from Google can make your services more powerful, reliable and performant.  You will learn from the experts in a hands-on live coding demonstration of planning, developing, deploying, scaling, monitoring and diagnosing issues in a production application. We will walk through the process of building a highly scalable nodejs backend for an iOS and Android based game.  We will touch on the latest technologies Google Cloud Platform has to offering include: Machine learning via the Vision API, App Engine Flexible Environment, StackDriver monitoring and diagnosis. You will walk away ready to build what’s NEXT with Google Cloud Platform.

sessions.title: V8, modern JavaScript, and beyond
sessions.description: JavaScript powers the modern web and countless servers running Node.js. Chrome's V8 engine is faster than ever at running JavaScript code and now includes powerful new ES2015 features to give developers more control over how they write their apps. Listen to Seth Thompson talk about the latest speed advances V8 has made in compiling and running real-world code and how those performance improvements scale to large JavaScript frameworks running on a wide variety of devices. Finally, hear about the future of fast code in the browser with WebAssembly: a new cross-browser, plugin-free, low-level runtime for executing C/C++ code on the web.

01258cc7-8ff6-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Alan  Viverette
01258cc7-8ff6-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Alan works on the Android framework's UI Toolkit team and is tech lead for the Android support library. Prior to working at Google, Alan received a bachelor's degree in Computer Science from Stanford University.

016d41c3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Chris Banes
016d41c3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Chris is an engineer working on the Android Support Libraries at Google, most notably AppCompat, Design lib and Palette. He has worked on Android things for over 6 years, from open source libraries to media apps, social networks and most stuff in between.

01cad1a5-a70f-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Glen  Shires
01cad1a5-a70f-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Glen Shires is a speech software engineer who led the development of the Google Cloud Speech API and the Chrome Web Speech API. He also chaired the W3C Speech API group and has been granted over a dozen patents. Prior to joining Google in 2010, he led development teams for voice and speech products at Intel, General Magic and Picazo Communications. Glen received his bachelor's and master's degrees in electrical and computer engineering from the University of Wisconsin - Madison, where he developed a speech-recognition engine for his master's thesis.

01fa3f2c-9efa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Mark Mandel
01fa3f2c-9efa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Mark Mandel is a Developer Advocate for Google Cloud Platform and one half of the Google Cloud Platform Podcast. Hailing from Australia, Mark built his career developing backend systems for over 15 years and authoring and contributing to several widely adopted open source projects.  When he's not building infrastructure in the cloud, he's constantly looking for new and interesting things he can do with Docker containers, playing with his dog and reading too much fantasy literature.

0226fec9-2c05-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: John Hoford
0226fec9-2c05-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: John is a developer on Android.   He has worked on Android Studio, RenderScript, Vector Drawables, computed shadows and photo editor filters. Prior to joining Google, John was a principal engineer at GE Healthcare working on their image processing applications framework.

03843d0a-8afa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Casey Burkhardt
03843d0a-8afa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Casey creates technologies to improve the accessibility of Google's mobile platforms. He also builds tools that allow developers to improve the accessibility of their applications. Previously, Casey led development of Android's screen reader, TalkBack. Casey earned both a bachelor's and a master's degree in computer science from Villanova University.

03e21705-f6fc-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Victor Chan
03e21705-f6fc-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Victor is building the future of automotive user experiences as a software engineer on the Android Auto team. Previously, he worked on the Android app for Google+. Prior to Google, Victor was a cofounder of a sports social network startup and a member of technical staff at Oracle Labs. 

Victor has a S.M. in Computer Science from Harvard University and a bachelor's degree in Computer Science from the University of British Columbia.

041487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Rob Dodson
041487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Rob Dodson is a developer advocate at Google where he focuses on Polymer and Web Components. His mission is to fight for a better web and to help developers build great experiences.

0653e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Tingmui Li
0653e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Tingmui is a Product Manager for Cloud Messaging, focusing on building messaging product that (re)connects developers with their users effectively. 
Prior to Google, she was a product manager at a startup, building a social and local app; a management consultant, advising technology companies on business and operational strategies; an engineering lead in a mobile company, launching products to hundreds of millions of users.
Tingmui has an INSEAD MBA, Stanford MSc and University of Virginia BSc degrees.

0709dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Paul Irish
0709dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Paul Irish is a front-end developer who loves the web. He works on Google Chrome, its performance and DevTools.

0751e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Mike McDonald
0751e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Mike helps developers build better mobile apps as an iOS engineer and product manager on the Firebase team. Mike has been with Firebase for two years, and has worked at the Omni Group and Texas Instruments. He graduated with a degree in Computer Engineering and Computer Science from Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology.

083cdcf7-b6f3-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Kunal Soni
083cdcf7-b6f3-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Kunal has been with Google for over five years and currently leads partnerships and business development for Google Play in South East Asia, India and Australia.

08921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Chris Wilson
08921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Chris Wilson is a Developer Advocate for the Open Web platform..  He started working on web browsers in 1993 when he co-authored the original Windows version of NCSA Mosaic, worked on Internet Explorer for fifteen years at Microsoft, and joined Google in 2010.  He co-chairs the Web Incubation Community Group, is on the W3C Advisory Board, and just generally tries to make the web great.  He loves enabling awesome user experiences on the web.

090ed6d8-79f8-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Florian Bertele
090ed6d8-79f8-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Florian is a product manager on the Maps API team. In his role, he focuses on the Places API across all platforms and geographies. Florian has an MBA from INSEAD. He earned a Diplom (M.Sc.) in Computer Science from the University of Ulm, Germany.

09453f39-26f5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Manuel Clement
09453f39-26f5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: I am a Lead UX Designer and Prototyper on Daydream. I have worked on Material Design, Chrome, the Self-Driving Car, and Google Doodles! I love to make music, teach kids programming, and practice Wing Chun Kung Fu.

0d53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Jennifer W. Lin
0d53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Jennifer is the lead for App Indexing. Prior to that, she worked on Google Sign-In and Mobile Ads at Google. She earned a master's degree in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science from MIT.

0e8dd55a-0a0b-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Luis Hector Chavez
0e8dd55a-0a0b-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Luis is one of the engineers in the Chrome OS team. He was also involved in developing App Runtime for Chrome. Prior to Google, he was a software engineer in the Ranking Platform team at Bing in Microsoft. Luis earned a Bachelor's degree in computer science from ITESM-Campus Queretaro.

0eaf2fcf-89fa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Astrid Weber
0eaf2fcf-89fa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Astrid Weber is working as a User Experience Researcher inside the Google Research Group at Google Head Quarters in Mountain View, California. She works on accessibility and usability with a focus on voice operated interfaces. Astrid speaks regularly at conferences and panels about human centered design. She graduated from the University of the Arts in Berlin with a Master in Design and Communication Research.

0f09dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Rob Jagnow
0f09dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Rob is a Software Engineer on Google's virtual reality team, where he aims to prototype a new VR experience every week. Prior to joining Google, Rob was the Founder and CEO of Lazy 8 Studios, a small game studio in San Francisco best known for its hit mobile game Cogs and it's groundbreaking alternate reality game Extrasolar. Rob earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science from MIT with a focus on computer graphics.

0f56ed97-da07-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Rachel Garb
0f56ed97-da07-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Rachel leads the UX team responsible for the Android OS. Before joining Google in 2005, she worked at TiVo, AOL, and several startups. She holds a master's degree in educational technology from Harvard University.

10381b4b-8b0a-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Francoise Beaufays
10381b4b-8b0a-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Françoise leads a team of engineers, researchers and linguists working on Speech Recognition and Input Methods (Google Keyboard). Her research interests focus on Machine Learning and Neural Networks, and on bringing their magic to technology users around the world. Françoise holds a PhD in Electrical Engineering and a PhD minor in Italian Literature from Stanford University.

116eb8c4-7df8-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Pasha  Nahass
116eb8c4-7df8-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Pasha Nahass is a Product Manager at Google working on in-app ad formats.  Prior to Google, he was a software engineer at Amazon.com.  Pasha earned his bachelor's and master's degrees in Computer Science from Stanford University.

12e97664-5e03-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Shaan  Basak
12e97664-5e03-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Susnata is an engineer in the Android TV team and working on Leanback Api. Prior to joining Google, he has worked as an engineer with different groups ranging from retail to payment risk monitoring in Amazon and PayPal. Susnata earned his Bachelors degree in Computer Engineering from Jadavpur University in India and he did his Master's in Computer Scrience from Tulsa University in Oklahoma.

1609dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Nibha Jain
1609dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Nibha leads the Emerging Markets research at YouTube. She enjoys developing new frameworks, guidelines and research tools and techniques that can help researchers and other team functions understand their users better.

1751e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Wim Meeussen
1751e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Wim joined Google in 2014 and leads the Tango Location team. His mission is to use computer vision to bring location-based experiences to mobile devices. Before joining Google, Wim was a co-founder of hiDOF, and worked on personal robotics at Willow Garage.

18437094-eef5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Basheer Tome
18437094-eef5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Basheer is a hybrid industrial & interaction designer working on input for VR, crafting new interfaces that transform digital processes into analog interactions. He has worked at Google in various capacities from user experience design on Hangouts to interaction research for X.

Prior to joining Google, his work focused on creating clever, digitally-native kitchen appliances from toasters to timers. Basheer earned an M.S. with the Tangible Media group at the MIT Media Lab and a B.S. in Industrial Design from Georgia Tech.

18486da0-0617-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Mario Klingemann
18486da0-0617-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Mario, AKA Quasimondo, is what you get when you cross the analytic mind of a coder with the creative fervor of an artist, and add a little bit of mad scientist mentality to the mix. In his aim to surprise himself and his audience, he consistently explores uncharted territories in order to discover unseen beauty and unthought ideas. A key factor in his work is the drive to overcome limitations by creatively repurposing and recombining objects and systems to reveal hidden qualities. His creations have been exhibited in international art shows and have won acclaim among critics as exemplary pieces of net art. Pieces like Mona Tweeta, ScribblerToo, Flickeur, Dada Visualization, Like This or his Pie Packing series have made their way into uncounted best-of lists and been featured in many articles. He enjoys sharing his explorations and discoveries at design and technology conferences worldwide, has co-founded the Munich FabLab and is working as a freelance creative coder and visualist.

194c6ded-0317-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Peter Poirier
194c6ded-0317-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Over the past 13 years Peter has worked in Canon’s Seattle area office managing a number of development projects relating to mobile and desktop printing and has been an active member of the Mopria Alliance from its inception.   Prior to joining Canon he worked in developing embedded firmware for the printing industry and holds Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering from California State Polytechnic University.

1a4c22aa-15fc-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Dawid  Ostrowski
1a4c22aa-15fc-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Dawid is a Program Manager in Developer Relations team, currently leading Google Developer Experts Program globally. He joined Google to be in a place where the best humans create and use the best technology. He wants to make developers successful in building applications and businesses on Google's developer platforms and APIs. Prior to joining Google, Dawid worked as a freelance developer and trainer in projects of various size (from small startups to biggest players on the market) in Poland, USA, Germany, Belgium and The Netherlands.

1aa45f76-5e03-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Keyvan Amiri
1aa45f76-5e03-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Keyvan is a software engineer in the Android TV team, and has been working on developing Leanback APIs for TV. Prior to that, he was an intern at Amazon working on developing UI for monitoring real-time interaction among different services.

Keyvan has a PhD and Masters degree from Rice University in Electrical and Computer Engineering with a Computer Science emphasis. His research focused on evaluating performance of protocols in multihop wireless networks.

1b1487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Shona Dutta
1b1487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Shona is a visual designer on the Android design team. She's designed for Google Keep, Google Fit, Clock, Calculator, and currently designs the new Brillo/Weave experiences. Shona came to Google as part of an acquisition of Bump Technologies and worked at a number of startups in the Bay Area. She attended the Rhode Island School of Design, where she earned her bachelor's degree in Graphic Design.

1c0b15f8-dff5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Brett Lider
1c0b15f8-dff5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Brett is the design lead for Android Wear, helping define experiences that are glanceable and actionable, so that users can get things done and get back to whatever they were doing. He has been working at Google as a designer for eleven years. Brett is also credited with discovering the ideal bicycling commuting route from San Francisco to Mountain View.

Brett has a bachelor’s degree in Cognitive Science from the University of Virginia.

1c51d8c8-0617-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Cyril Diagne
1c51d8c8-0617-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Cyril is a professor of Interaction Design at ECAL (Lausanne, Switzerland), a co-founder of the collective LAB212 and an artist in residence at the Google Cultural Institute Lab (Paris, France).

1c53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Peter Lubbers
1c53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Peter Lubbers is a Senior Program Manager at Google on the Developer Relations team. He is in charge of all aspects of developer training, developer vIdeo, and developer events. In 2010, he started the San Francisco HTML5 Developer Group, which is now the world’s largest HTML5 developer meetup. He is the author of “Pro HTML5 Programming” (Apress, 2011) and even has the HTML5 license plate on his car! A native of the Netherlands, Peter served as a Special Forces commando in the Royal Dutch Green Berets. When he is not at home or out running triple marathons around Lake Tahoe you might see him jump out of a plane.

1d4053cf-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Adam Champy
1d4053cf-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Adam Champy is a Product Manager at Google focusing on living room products such as Chromecast and Chromecast Audio. He leads the Google Cast SDK as well as other areas of hardware development, including the recently launched program that enables Google Cast, the same technology behind Chromecast, on Vizio Displays. Adam previously led areas of DoubleClick's ad buying solutions, including DoubleClick Planning as well as audience measurement and targeting. Before Google, Adam worked as a consultant at The Boston Consulting Group and was an engineer at Analog Devices with a focus on inertial sensing chips. 

Adam earned Bachelor and Masters degrees from MIT in Computer Science and Electrical Engineering and an MBA from The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

1e1a630d-22f5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Jason Sanmiya
1e1a630d-22f5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Jason writes open source C++ game technology with Fun Propulsion Labs at Google. He led his team's most recent sample game, Zooshi, which you can find on the Play Store. Before Google, Jason worked Electronic Arts, where his locomotion system animated the FIFA and Madden franchises.

1e8a5289-4c0e-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Kevin Schaaf
1e8a5289-4c0e-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Kevin is a software engineer focusing on core features of the Polymer library. Kevin got his start in web development at a Tokyo startup back in the Netscape/IE5 days, and then took a long hiatus from the web while working in embedded electronics. Kevin returned back to the web in full force several years ago after joining Palm to work on the webOS developer platform and later leading the development of LG’s smart TV UI framework before joining the Polymer team at Google.

1f35020c-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Bhavik Singh
1f35020c-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Bhavik Singh is a Product Manager on Android focusing on Android Sensors, Location and Context Awareness APIs. He has been at Google for two years, and has a Bachelors degree in Computer Science from U.C Berkeley. In his free time he likes Painting, Hiking and exploring San Francisco.

20882df0-0117-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Brent Richtsmeier
20882df0-0117-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Brent Richtsmeier is the Vice President of Development for the Solutions Innovation Group at Samsung Research America. He has over 30 years of industry experience fostering innovation, creation of IP, and enabling productivity solutions. Most recently he led the vision and creation of the Smart UX platform and the ecosystem which integrates Mobility and Print. Brent also is the chair of the Mopria (Mobile Print) steering committee, and leads the innovation for the Solutions Group Cloud Platform.

20921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Frank van Puffelen
20921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Frank is an engineer for Firebase at Google. He helps developers build extraordinary apps that use Firebase as their back-end. If you've ever asked a Firebase question on StackOverflow, you've probably met Frank already. Frank has a degree in Medical Computer Science from The Hague University in The Netherlands.

20a3bb45-33f5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Maurice  Chu
20a3bb45-33f5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Maurice Chu, Technical Lead Manager

Maurice leads the Awareness project in the Android Location and Context team, focusing on bringing context awareness to the mobile ecosystem.  Prior to Google, Maurice was a researcher at the Palo Alto Research Center (formerly known as Xerox PARC), working on sensor networks, ubiquitous computing, and context aware systems.  Maurice earned a B.S., M.Eng, and Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering and computer science from MIT.

217f6b3b-0dfc-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Dillon  Cower
217f6b3b-0dfc-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Dillon is a Software Engineer working on spatial audio and creator tools for VR media. Prior to Google, he worked on low-level compiler optimization at IBM. Dillon holds a bachelor's degree in Computer Science from York University and works in Seattle.

2333f7c5-eef5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Bruno Oliveira
2333f7c5-eef5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Bruno Oliveira is a Software Engineer in the VR team at Google, working on several projects on various levels of the VR stack, including SDKs to enable developers to create exciting VR experiences with Google's technology.

Born in Sao Paulo, Brazil, Bruno joined Google in 2010 and worked on several projects including Orkut, Android, the Google Play Games team and the Artificial Intelligence team prior to joining the Google VR effort.

2453e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Adrian Ludwig
2453e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Adrian Ludwig is the lead engineer for Android security at Google.  In this role, he is responsible for the security of the Android platform and Google's applications and services for Android. Prior to joining Google, Adrian held technical leadership positions at Joyent, Adobe, Macromedia, @stake, and the Department of Defense. Adrian has a BA in Mathematics from Williams College and an MBA from the University of California, Berkeley.

246356ab-f50a-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Ben  Galbraith
246356ab-f50a-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Ben Galbraith is the head of product and developer relations for Google's Developer Product Group. Prior to Google, Ben has alternated between entrepreneurial and executive roles across companies in many industries, such as Mozilla, Palm / HP, and Walmart. He lives in Palo Alto with his wife and eight children.

25016b77-9dfa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Ian Lewis
25016b77-9dfa-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Ian is a Developer Advocate on the Google Cloud Platform team working out of Tokyo. Ian loves Python and Go and helps run the largest Python event in Japan, PyCon JP. Ian is also interested in Docker and Kubernetes and hopes to help Google Cloud Platform users achieve their highest potential.

254053cf-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Chuo-Ling Chang
254053cf-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Chuo-Ling leads all streaming efforts in the App Streaming project. Prior to Google, he was an engineering lead for streaming and networking at Agawi Inc., acquired by Google in 2014. He has also worked as a senior scientist and engineer specialized in multimedia processing and streaming in startups such as Tokbox Inc. and Dyyno Inc. Chuo-Ling holds a BS degree in Electrical Engineering from National Taiwan University, and a MS and PhD degree also in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.

2551e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Raghavan Menon
2551e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Raghavan is a product lead on Firebase. He came to Google from Nimbuz Inc (Odysee) where he was co-founder and CEO. Prior to Google/Nimbuz, he was co-founder and CTO at Ingot Systems till its acquisition by Virage Logic. His team builds products that drive user acquisition and engagement for apps.

25cd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Eric Bidelman
25cd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Eric is a Senior Staff Developer Programs Engineer at Google working with the Chrome team, Polymer, and web components. He's the author of “Using the HTML5 Filesystem API” and has led frontend projects like the Google I/O web app, Google's Santa tracker, chromestatus.com, and html5rocks.com. Prior to Google, Eric worked as a software engineer at the University of Michigan where he designed rich web applications and APIs for the university’s 19 libraries.

2609dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Wojtek Kalicinski
2609dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Wojtek provides outreach to developers on new Android framework features, tools and testing as part of his job as a Senior Developer Advocate. He has worked with Android since the early days of the platform and enjoys looking for ways to make apps more usable, mostly through better development patterns and code optimizations. Prior to working at Google, Wojtek was a co-founder and CTO at a digital agency startup. For many years he was also involved in organizing and speaking at community events through Google Developer Groups.

2a1487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: David East
2a1487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: David East is a Developer Advocate at Google. He's been developing with Firebase for almost three years now. Prior to Google, David worked at Firebase when it was just a wee little startup. He completed a Computer Science degree from Radford University.

2b53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Shazia Makhdumi
2b53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Shazia Makhdumi oversees global business development for family apps and games on Google Play.  Her team is responsible for finding the best family-friendly apps and games and  bringing them to Play.  They work with developers worldwide to help them grow their businesses on Android, and with internal teams to influence product development within key areas including business models, discovery and distribution. 
 
Shazia has spent over 15 years in the Internet industry, from Netscape in the early days of the Internet to her own venture ColorStories, an app allowing kids to create personalized books.   She holds a BS and MS in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from MIT, and an MBA from Stanford.

2d29e315-2bf5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Ian Kelly
2d29e315-2bf5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Ian Kelly is a software engineer in the Spatial Audio group, he works on signal processing algorithms for Google VR. Ian joined Google in January 2015 as part of an acquisition. Before that Ian was a founding member of Thrive Audio, an Irish based, spatial audio startup. Prior to Thrive Audio Ian completed a PhD in audio signal processing at Trinity College, University of Dublin. Here his research focused on the analysis and digital processing of acoustic impulse responses for immersive audio.

2d4053cf-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: TI Chang
2d4053cf-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: TI Chang is a Developer Advocate working with game developers to improve gaming experience in Android and Google Play. Before joining Google, he was the research director at Com2uS and led the development of mobile games and the gaming platforms for them. He also worked as a development director in the PC online game project in EA. TI earned Ph. D degree in Computer Science from Pohang University of Science and Technology in Korea.

2d51e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Timo Mertens
2d51e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Timo Mertens is a product manager working on Google Search. He has worked on user and developer facing products in the space of App Indexing, Voice Actions and Personalized Search. Before joining Google Timo was at Microsoft where he worked on Voice Recognition for Xbox and Cortana. He also was a visiting researcher at MIT and Microsoft Research, and holds a PhD in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from NTNU.

2dcd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Michael Bleigh
2dcd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Michael is the tech lead for Firebase Hosting and the Firebase Command-Line Interface. Prior to Google, Michael was co-founder of developer-focused startup Divshot, whose technology now powers Firebase Hosting. He has also been active in the open-source community, creating popular Ruby libraries such as OmniAuth, Grape, and MultiJson.

2e09dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Julius Kammerl
2e09dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Julius coordinates the spatial audio efforts for Google VR as a senior software engineer and has been contributing to several features of its SDK. Prior to Google, Julius was a research engineer at Willow Garage working on open source software for robotics. He also worked as a researcher at the Audio and Multimedia Group at Fraunhofer Institute for Integrated Circuits IIS in Erlangen/Germany. Julius earned a Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from the Technische Universitaet Muenchen (TUM), Germany.

2f921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Maya Ben Ari
2f921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Maya is leading Android Accessibility efforts to make technology usable for everyone. Previously, she led the next generation of the Android Lock Screen and Fingerprint to give users better security without the hassle of entering passwords. Prior to Google, Maya worked for Microsoft as an on-campus representative and helped design their university strategy. Maya is a technology enthusiast and was heavily involved in the Israeli startup community, co-founding two startups. She earned a bachelor’s and master’s degree in Computer Science from Tel-Aviv University, and an MBA from University of Michigan.

2fd22fe1-fbff-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Damien Henry
2fd22fe1-fbff-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Damien Henry is a Technical Program Manager for the Google Cultural Institute and co-inventor of Google Cardboard. He directs a small team of creative coders and organises an artist residency based in Paris. Damien has been coding since the age of 10 and has academic background in mechanics and acoustics. Prior to Google, Damien was CTO of a voice analysis company and co-founded AudioGaming, a sound synthesis startup. He is also the creator of Novelab, a small studio focused on cutting-edge technologies. He is passionate about applying virtual reality and machine learning to art and culture.

311487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Brahim Elbouchikhi
311487d5-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Brahim Elbouchikhi is a Senior Product Manager on the Google VR team. Prior to joining the VR team, Brahim led monetization, search, and discovery on the Google Play store. Brahim holds an MBA from the Stanford Graduate School of Business and a BS in Computer Science and Engineering from UCLA. Brahim has also worked at Amazon and Deloitte in addition to starting a company in the past.

3353e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Alfonso Gómez-Jordana
3353e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Alfonso coordinates the implementation of developer tools related to identity and authentication. Previously, he has worked as product manager for the reCAPTCHA team, during part of the design and early development phases of the recent no-captcha reCAPTCHA release. Prior to Google, Alfonso has worked as a Software Engineer in Android for Facebook, as well as smaller startups.

Alfonso graduated with degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration from Universidad Carlos III of Madrid, Spain.

3509dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Akshay Kannan
3509dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Akshay is the Product Manager for Nearby and other initiatives in the Location and Context space. He focuses on using the sensors and hardware on devices to power new and exciting experiences. Prior to joining Android, Akshay has worked on the Google Cloud Platform and on Google Chrome. Akshay graduated from UC Berkeley in 2011 with a bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science.

3535020c-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Steven Soneff
3535020c-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Steven is product manager for Google's developer APIs for authentication, including Google Sign-In and Smart Lock for Passwords. He previously worked as an engineer on Android apps at Google, did development at several start-up companies, and wrote the original Facebook Android SDK launched in 2010.

3551e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Vincent Mo
3551e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Vincent is a Technical Lead Manager on the Android Auto team.  Previously, Vincent was on the Platforms Infrastructure Engineering team helping keep Google's data centers up and running.  Prior to Google, Vincent was a software engineer at EADS North America Test & Services.  Vincent earned his Computer and Electrical Engineering degrees from the University of California, Irvine.

35cd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Sabine Borsay
35cd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Sabine is a Product Manager on the Chrome team and has been at Google for over six years. She is currently managing Authentication and Privacy features in Chrome. 

Prior to Google, Sabine worked as a User Experience Designer and Researcher at IBM. She earned a bachelor’s and master’s degree in Computer Science from the University of Hamburg, Germany, where she also worked on academic research in the field of Computational Neuroscience.

3727c482-a2ff-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Alan  Ni
3727c482-a2ff-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Alan works as a product manager on developer experience for AdMob.  As a former software engineer, Alan can sympathize with developer pain points and strives to make integrating with AdMob a great experience.  Alan graduated from Duke University with a Computer Science major and Economics minor.

37921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Wouter Van Oortmerssen
37921d18-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Wouter's mission at Google is to make game developers life easier, with efficient libraries such as FlatBuffers, FPLBase and FlatUI. He comes from a background of game development (Crytek, more recently Maxis / Gearbox) teaching (The Guildhall) and open source (Cube Engine, TreeSheets, Lobster..). He also has the bad habit of creating way too many new programming languages, taking confusing pictures, and racing fast cars (though not necessarily at the same time).

37b79e39-0017-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Kate Paduchowski
37b79e39-0017-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Kate is the Senior Product Manager at Walgreen Co. overseeing the award-winning Walgreens Android app. She drives world class execution and delivery of products providing customers with ultimate access, choice and convenience. Prior to Walgreens, Kate worked in product management at Cars.com and Chicago Tribune.

380e1b7a-2bf5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Andrew Bunner
380e1b7a-2bf5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Andrew Bunner is the engineering lead for Nearby, Google's multi-platform proximity solution. Before Google, Andrew lead development teams at several start-ups in ecommerce and web publishing. He received a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

3a53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Eitan Marder-Eppstein
3a53e3f3-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Eitan Marder-Eppstein is the Developer Engineering Lead for Google's Project Tango - a focused effort to bring computer vision and advanced sensor fusion to mobile platforms. Previously, he worked in robotics as President of hiDOF, and as a core contributor to the Robot Operating System (ROS) at Willow Garage. Eitan has a B.S. and M.S. in Computer Science from Washington University in St. Louis.

3a717acb-2410-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Mike Podwal
3a717acb-2410-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Mike Podwal is a Product Manager on Daydream, where he focuses on VR apps. He previously led product for Jump and Cardboard Camera. Prior to Google, Mike worked at Amazon on Kindle.

3b69d79e-0217-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Jeremy Reitz
3b69d79e-0217-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Over the past 16 years Jeremy has had multiple software development and management roles at Xerox in Rochester, NY.  Currently Jeremy is the Global Development Manager at Xerox for Mobility and Hosted Printer Solutions.  Previous to current responsibilities, Jeremy served as the Mopria Technical Working group Chair and holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Computer Engineering from Penn State.

3c09dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Glenn Kasten
3c09dbe7-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Glenn is a software engineer in the Android media team, with a focus on low-level audio and performance. His background includes real-time operating systems and embedded applications, and he enjoys playing piano.

3d35020c-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: JP Souchak
3d35020c-c3ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
JP is a program manager on the Google Developer Training team. In this role, he focuses on developer certification for Android and online training for the Google Cloud Platform. He has also worked on training metrics and developed courseware for Firebase and GCE. Prior to Google, he developed training at Cloudera and managed education, training, and documentation at RightScale and Openwave Systems, Inc.

JP earned master’s degrees from Colorado State University and Pacifica Graduate Institute. He also earned a bachelor’s degree in English from Penn State University.

3d51e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Anirudh Mohan
3d51e0f9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Ani is a product manager on the Chrome team focusing on bluetooth and connectivity efforts. Previously, he worked on the Next Billion Users team building hardware and services for users in emerging markets. Ani earned a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering from Duke University.

3dcd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Thomas Bouldin
3dcd40c9-c2ee-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Thomas is a senior software engineer at Google. His work with the Firebase team ranges from API design to backend reliability and performance. Before Firebase, Thomas was an early engineer at Parse. He had a hand in many Parse products and is best known as the lead developer for Parse Push. Previously Thomas was an engineer on Google's Image Search infrastructure and Microsoft Windows.

Thomas Earned his bachelor’s degree in software engineering at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo with a focus on computer graphics and operating systems & security.

3e351540-8c11-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: John Giannandrea
3e351540-8c11-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
John Giannandrea is the Senior Vice President of Engineering for Search, Machine Intelligence, and the Web at Google. In this role, John is responsible for overseeing product and business development in these areas, as well as leading longer-term technology initiatives at the company.  

John joined Google in 2010 following the acquisition of Metaweb, a company that he co-founded with Danny Hillis, and whose technology became the foundation for the Google Knowledge Graph.  Previously John was a co-founder and CTO of Tellme Networks, which was acquired by Microsoft Corporation in 2007. 

John is a native of Scotland and a graduate of the University of Strathclyde.

3eba9cec-f50a-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Jamie Rosenberg
3eba9cec-f50a-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio:
Jamie is vice president of Google Play. He leads a cross-functional team that includes product development, engineering, content merchandising, business partnerships and operations for Google Play, Google’s digital content store offering apps, games, music, movies, books and more.

Prior to Google, Jamie was vice president of premium services for Danger, Inc. He also worked for Redpoint Ventures as well as stints at NBA, Sports Illustrated, ESPN and Disney Online. Jamie has a bachelor’s degree from University of North Carolina and an MBA from Stanford.

3f4480b4-4a12-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Katherine Walker
3f4480b4-4a12-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: Katherine Walker is a Design Lead with Google’s Brand Studio, where she helps define and craft the Google experience. Before coming to Google, Katherine lived in Chicago, where she was an ACD at VSA Partners and a member of the AIGA Chicago board and Director of the AIGA Mentor Program. As part of her commitment to pragmatic idealism, Katherine co­founded Quite Strong, a design collaborative focused on empowering female creatives through community-oriented events. Her work has been recognized in Dwell, TimeOut, and other publications.

40763054-0ef5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.name: JP Gil
40763054-0ef5-e511-a517-00155d5066d7.bio: JP is a designer in the Android Wear team, where he focuses on making app experiences awesome. He's also one of the co-founders of the internal 20% project that became Android Wear. Prior to Google he worked as designer for agencies in Europe, designing experiences for big and small clients. JP has a background in computer science, design and communication.

414b1e55-8f11-e611-a517-00155d5066d7.name: Kara Erickson
